text.sentence: Airline management says: We all have learned to be a little more prudent in how we run our businesses over the last six or seven years.
We have been in a five year up cycle and I think the industry is not going to be as cyclical in the future as it was in the past.
Airline investor says: Right now all the stars are lined up .

Gary Wilson, Chairman of Northwest, quoted in a May one thousand nine hundred ninety eight CNN Money article; Christian Stadlinger, Compass Small Cap Value in a January one thousand nine hundred ninety eight Barron's article.
We get why the market is skeptical of predictions from airline executives that the industry has changed ­ we've heard it before.
We also can't ignore that the market has a better track record on these matters than management.
Airline stocks, for instance, peaked in mid one thousand nine hundred ninety eight before a historically bad downturn by two thousand two four.
Bold management statements of the past, unfortunately, all too often came with the same old ineffective decisions.
So here we sit, arguably at or near cyclical peak margins ­ depending on where oil bottoms ­ with an understandable sense of déjà vu.
That said, this peak is notable as, in our view, current margins do provide evidence that normalized earnings power for AAL and the US industry is much improved.

Consider this: LUV, which did create shareholder value until two thousand one, is more profitable than it was in the one thousand nine hundred ninetys, but also as close to being an `average airline' as it has ever been.

Beyond margins, a telling metric, capex to revenue, remains well below the one thousand nine hundred ninetys peak and the industry is actually buying fewer airplanes at ~ dollar thirty oil than we forecast a few years ago.

Industry behavior hasn't been perfect, oil has been more impactful to pricing than expected, but on balance we actually feel a bit better about the industry structure than we did at dollar one hundred/bbl oil.

It may prove to be a foolish forecast, but we think at ~fivex our two thousand sixteen EPS, AAL and legacy airline valuation in general, is depressed beyond just discounting for `peak margin' and low oil.

U.S. Airlines Industry View: POSITIVE Stock Rating: OVERWEIGHT two thousand sixteenE forty thousand five hundred fifteen ten thousand five hundred two nine thousand two hundred seventy six thousand seven hundred thirty seven four thousand one hundred seventy seven six.seventy five six hundred nineteen.one

two two thousand seventeenE forty three thousand six hundred fifteen eight thousand twenty one six thousand seven hundred ninety three three thousand eight hundred sixty eight two thousand four hundred thirty seven four.fifteen five hundred eighty six.six .fifty
eight two thousand eighteenE forty one thousand five hundred sixty five three thousand nine hundred two two thousand six hundred seventy four three hundred seventeen two hundred .thirty
Fundamentals for AAL look promising given the competitive cost structure and the potential for relative RASM improvements.
As a result, we think that DAL like margins at AAL are likely but may take longer than some expect.
Our upside scenario assumes fuel stays low through two thousand sixteen with much more limited revenue offset.
The two thousand sixteenE EPS would be dollar six.seventy seven and the P/E multiple becomes eleven.sevenx.
Our downside scenario assumes that the two thousand sixteen base EPS misses by twelve percent and the current multiple contracts to four.threex.

Income statement Revenue EBITDAR EBITDA Pre tax income Net income EPS Diluted shares DPS Margin and return data EBITDAR margin EBIT margin Pre tax margin Net margin ROIC ROA ROE Balance sheet and cash flow Tangible fixed assets Intangible fixed assets Cash and equivalents Total assets Short and long term debt Other long term liabilities Total liabilities Adj net debt Shareholders' equity Change in working capital Cash flow from operations Capital expenditure Free cash flow Valuation and leverage metrics P/E EV/EBITDAR Equity FCF yield EV/sales Dividend yield Adj net debt/capital Selected operating metrics Fuel dollar /gal ASM growth Load factor Yield growth PRASM growth Non fuel CASM growth
Our oneQ EPS estimate moves down to dollar one.twenty on softer RASM guide of versus our and a bit higher fuel .
Consolidated CASM ex fuel looks to be up ~two percent, that is also higher than we'd expected to start the year, and on a bit more capacity.
Our full year outlook comes down to dollar six.seventy five as we carry some revenue softness into summer, but also higher absolute non fuel costs.
CASM ex for 'sixteen is as we'd expected, but on higher capacity, which also plays into softer RASM assumptions.
percent for two thousand sixteen given lower and lower fuel prices.

For the moment we have a smaller share repurchase in two thousand sixteen than two thousand fifteen, although we do have a cash build that would put the company~ dollar onebn above the announced liquidity target of dollar six.fivebn.

Guide to the Barclays Fundamental Equity Research Rating System: Our coverage analysts use a relative rating system in which they rate stocks as Overweight, Equal Weight or Underweight relative to other companies covered by the analyst or a team of analysts that are deemed to be in the same industry .
In addition to the stock rating, we provide industry views which rate the outlook for the industry coverage universe as Positive, Neutral or Negative .
A rating system using terms such as buy, hold and sell is not the equivalent of our rating system.
Investors should carefully read the entire research report including the definitions of all ratings and not infer its contents from ratings alone.
Stock Rating Overweight The stock is expected to outperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a twelve month investment horizon.
Equal Weight The stock is expected to perform in line with the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a twelvemonth investment horizon.
Underweight The stock is expected to underperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a twelve month investment horizon.

Rating Suspended The rating and target price have been suspended temporarily due to market events that made coverage impracticable or to comply with applicable regulations and/or firm policies in certain circumstances including where the Investment Bank of Barclays Bank PLC is acting in an advisory capacity in a merger or strategic transaction involving the company.
Neutral industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are steady, neither improving nor deteriorating.

Below is the list of companies that constitute the industry coverage universe: U.S. Airlines AerCap Holdings Alaska Air Group Delta Air Lines Spirit Airlines Distribution of Ratings: Barclays Equity Research has one thousand eight hundred eighty eight companies under coverage.

forty one percent have been assigned an Overweight rating which, for purposes of mandatory regulatory disclosures, is classified as a Buy rating; fifty nine percent of companies with this rating are investment banking clients of the Firm.

Guide to the Barclays Research Price Target: Each analyst has a single price target on the stocks that they cover.
The price target represents that analyst's expectation of where the stock will trade in the next twelve months.
Upside/downside scenarios, where provided, represent potential upside/potential downside to each analyst's price target over the same twelve month period.
Top Picks: Barclays Equity Research's Top Picks represent the single best alpha generating investment idea within each industry, taken from among the Overweight rated stocks within that industry.
Barclays Equity Research publishes global and regional Top Picks reports every quarter and analysts may also publish intra quarter changes to their Top Picks, as necessary.
While analysts one February two thousand sixteen five Air Lease Corp. Allegiant Travel Co. JetBlue Airways United Continental Holdings Aircastle Ltd.
may highlight other Overweight rated stocks in their published research in addition to their Top Pick, there can only be one Top Pick for each industry.

Valuation Methodology: Our PT of dollar fifty five is driven by a two thousand sixteenE P/E multiple of seven.fivex
and a two thousand sixteenE EPS of dollar six.seventy five .
Risks which May Impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Valuation and Price Target: Investing in AAL is risky.

Our target and rating are predicated on historical trading patterns and our current profit expectations, which hinge on our view that the supply and demand balance in the industry will improve substantially in the years to come allowing AAL to raise prices significantly.

If we have cause to question any of our assumptions about demand recovery, industry capacity decisions, various competitive forces, labor issues or geopolitical events among other things, we might be forced to make substantial and frequent changes to our profit expectations, targets, and recommendations
